bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, April 10, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] refers to the 1916 Gorgas report indicating that the fever in Muzo, Colombia was not yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, April 10, 1923
div1.opener:
I. H. B.
Columbia
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
April 10, 1923.
Dr. F. F. Russell,
General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Referring to the next to the last paragraph of Dr. Miller's
report, just received, I would say:

1/ The investigation of the mines of Muzo in 1916 was made by
Drs. Gorgas: Whitmore and Lyster: Guiteras and myself went to Bar-
anquilla.

2/ Two epidemics of yellow fever have been reported at this
place: the first in 1912 or 1914 by Dr. Franco, of which I have writ-
ten you: the second by the Alcalde, which was investigated by the
gentlemen mentioned above. Dr. Gorgas stated that there was no
sickness of any kind when he was there--that the Alcalde told him
that there had been none of any importance: that he had reported
cases and deaths from yellow fever because he judged from the tele-
grams of the Department of Health at Bogota that they wanted him to
do so and so complied. I judge this is given in Gorgas' report.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, S. D. to call white
